    Continuous Data Table

    Kyle Baron

    2020-06-02

    continuous-table.Rmd

    These functions create summary tables for continuous data. There is a long format and a wide format.

    Long format

    library(pmtables)
library(dplyr)

id <- pmtables:::data("id")

    A summary of covariates

    pt_cont_long(id, cols = "WT,ALB,SCR")
    Variable n1 Mean Median SD2 Min / Max
    All data
    WT 160 70.9 70.2 12.9 43.6 / 97.2
    ALB 160 4.19 4.31 0.809 1.28 / 5.39
    SCR 160 1.36 1.04 0.986 0.710 / 5.59

    1 subjects with non-missing values

    2 standard deviation

    Paneled summary

    Use the panel argument to split this by, for example, study

    pt_cont_long(
  id,
  cols = "WT,ALB,SCR",
  panel = vars(Study = STUDYf)
)
    Variable n1 Mean Median SD2 Min / Max
    Study 12-DEMO-001
    WT 30 72.9 71.0 14.6 50.9 / 97.2
    ALB 30 4.27 4.08 0.469 3.56 / 5.15
    SCR 30 1.03 1.04 0.155 0.740 / 1.30
    Study 12-DEMO-002
    WT 50 72.4 72.2 11.4 51.5 / 96.6
    ALB 50 4.47 4.43 0.468 3.65 / 5.39
    SCR 50 0.971 0.970 0.161 0.720 / 1.30
    Study 11-DEMO-005
    WT 40 69.2 65.8 14.4 43.6 / 92.8
    ALB 40 4.42 4.44 0.536 3.51 / 5.39
    SCR 40 2.52 2.33 1.43 0.720 / 5.59
    Study 13-DEMO-001
    WT 40 69.4 68.1 11.6 50.7 / 96.6
    ALB 40 3.53 3.46 1.15 1.28 / 5.38
    SCR 40 0.950 0.975 0.165 0.710 / 1.26
    All data
    WT 160 70.9 70.2 12.9 43.6 / 97.2
    ALB 160 4.19 4.31 0.809 1.28 / 5.39
    SCR 160 1.36 1.04 0.986 0.710 / 5.59

    1 subjects with non-missing values

    2 standard deviation

    Wide format

    There is also a wide format, where variable names go across the table.

    pt_cont_wide(id, cols = "WT,ALB,SCR")
    WT ALB SCR
    70.9 (12.9) [160] 4.19 (0.809) [160] 1.36 (0.986) [160]
    summary is: mean (standard deviation) [number non-missng]

    We can use the by argument here

    pt_cont_wide(id,cols="WT,ALB,SCR",by = vars(Study = STUDYf))
    Study WT ALB SCR
    12-DEMO-001 72.9 (14.6) [30] 4.27 (0.469) [30] 1.03 (0.155) [30]
    12-DEMO-002 72.4 (11.4) [50] 4.47 (0.468) [50] 0.971 (0.161) [50]
    11-DEMO-005 69.2 (14.4) [40] 4.42 (0.536) [40] 2.52 (1.43) [40]
    13-DEMO-001 69.4 (11.6) [40] 3.53 (1.15) [40] 0.950 (0.165) [40]
    All data 70.9 (12.9) [160] 4.19 (0.809) [160] 1.36 (0.986) [160]
    summary is: mean (standard deviation) [number non-missng]

    Or use by and panel

    pt_cont_wide(
  id,
  cols=vars(WT,ALB,SCR),
  by = vars(Study = STUDYf),
  panel=vars(Sex = SEXf)
)
    Study WT ALB SCR
    Sex: male
    12-DEMO-001 76.3 (16.8) [10] 4.33 (0.468) [10] 1.09 (0.174) [10]
    12-DEMO-002 72.0 (13.0) [18] 4.57 (0.497) [18] 1.01 (0.182) [18]
    11-DEMO-005 69.2 (15.0) [29] 4.46 (0.543) [29] 2.51 (1.46) [29]
    13-DEMO-001 71.1 (13.3) [23] 3.65 (0.993) [23] 0.922 (0.163) [23]
    Sex: female
    12-DEMO-001 71.2 (13.6) [20] 4.24 (0.478) [20] 1.01 (0.141) [20]
    12-DEMO-002 72.6 (10.6) [32] 4.42 (0.450) [32] 0.949 (0.146) [32]
    11-DEMO-005 69.1 (13.3) [11] 4.32 (0.524) [11] 2.53 (1.43) [11]
    13-DEMO-001 67.0 (8.74) [17] 3.36 (1.36) [17] 0.988 (0.164) [17]
    Total
    All data 70.9 (12.9) [160] 4.19 (0.809) [160] 1.36 (0.986) [160]
    summary is: mean (standard deviation) [number non-missng]
